columns.text: In this problem, we need to identify how much money is needed to be invested in Investment plan B in order for it to equal the returns for Investment plan A in 13 years.

Before we solve for the future value annuity of Investment A, we first need to get the rate. Since the given rate is compounded monthly, this means that there will be $12$ compounding periods in a year. Therefore, we will take the given rate and divide it by $12$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{rate}&=\dfrac{0.075}{12}\\[15 pt]
&=0.00625
\end{aligned}$$

The monthly rate is $0.00625$

Now that we have the rate, we can solve for the future value annuity of Investment A. Since we are using months as the time for this, we will represent $13$ years in terms of months which is $156$ months. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value annuity}&=\$1,250 \times\dfrac{(1+0.00625)^{156}-1}{0.00625}\\[15 pt]
&=\$328,627.03
\end{aligned}$$

The future value of the investment is $\$328,627.03$

For the rate, we will again divide the given monthly rate by $12$ since there are $12$ compounding periods in a year.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{rate}&=\dfrac{0.07}{12}\\[15 pt]
&=0.00583
\end{aligned}$$

The rate for this investment is $0.00583$

We can now substitute the values to the formula in Step 5. For the cash flow, we will use the future value for Investment A.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\dfrac{\$328,627.03}{(1+0.00583)^{156}}\\[15 pt]
&=\$132,699.12
\end{aligned}$$

The value of the lump sump to be invested in Investment plan B should be $\$132,699.12$
